{{infobox Organization |name = Tea Party Patriots |image = Tea Party Patriots Logo.png |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = |motto = Fiscal Responsibility, Limited Government, Free Markets |formation = 2009 |extinction = |type = [[501(c)(4)]] [[non-profit]] |status = |headquarters = [[Atlanta, Georgia]] |location = |region_served = |membership = |language = |leader_title = Co-founders |leader_name = [[Jenny Beth Martin]] and [[Mark Meckler]] |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.teapartypatriots.org/ TeaPartyPatriots.org] |remarks = }} '''Tea Party Patriots''' is a conservative American political organization that promotes fiscally responsible activism as part of the [[Tea Party movement]]. Its mission is "to attract, educate, organize, and mobilize our fellow citizens to secure public policy consistent with our three core values of Fiscal Responsibility, [[United States Constitution|Constitutionally]] Limited Government and [[Free market|Free Markets]]."<ref>[https://docs.google.com/View?id=dhsxmzm7_19fcdzskg5 Tea Party Patriots Mission Statement and Core Values]</ref> The group is a strong opponent of "excess" government spending and debt.<ref>[https://www.npr.org/2011/07/29/138820141/tea-party-patriots-dont-raise-debt-ceiling Tea Party Patriots: Don't Raise Debt Ceiling : NPR<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In 2010, the group reportedly included over 2,200 local chapters,<ref>Zernike, Kate. Boiling Mad: Inside Tea Party America. New York: Times /Henry Holt and, 2010. Print.</ref> as well as an online community of 115,311 members (estimated at 63% male, 31% female, 6% unspecified).<ref>Burghart, Devin, and Leonard Zeskind. Tea Party Nationalism: A Critical ExTea Party Movement and the Size, Scope, and Focus of Its National Factions. Rep. Institute for Research and Education on Human Rights, Fall 2010. Web. {{cite web |url=http://justanothercoverup.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/TeaPartyNationalism.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-01-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111124023305/http://justanothercoverup.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/TeaPartyNationalism.pdf |archivedate=2011-11-24 |df= }}</ref>
==History==
The organization was founded by [[Jenny Beth Martin]], [[Mark Meckler]], and [[Amy Kremer]] in March 2009.<ref>Burghart, Devin, and Leonard Zeskind. Tea Party Nationalism: A Critical Examination of the Tea Party Movement and the Size, Scope, and Focus of Its National Factions. Rep. Institute for Research and Education on Human Rights, Fall 2010. Web. {{cite web |url=http://justanothercoverup.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/TeaPartyNationalism.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-01-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111124023305/http://justanothercoverup.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/TeaPartyNationalism.pdf |archivedate=2011-11-24 |df= }}</ref>
Tea Party Patriots was a co-sponsor of the [[9/12 March on Washington]],<ref>[http://www.teapartypatriots.org/EventDetail/1920/912%20March%20and%20Rally Tea Party Patriots: 912 March and Rally]</ref> but refused to participate in the [[National Tea Party Convention]].<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/alex-brantzawadzki/tea-party-convention-lose_b_416987.html Alex Brant-Zawadzki: Tea Party Convention Loses Main Sponsor<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Tea Party Patriots is most notable for organizing citizen opposition at the [[America's Affordable Health Choices Act of 2009#Town halls|healthcare town hall meetings]] of 2009,<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/08/us/politics/08townhall.html?_r=1&hpHealth "Beyond Beltway, Health Debate Turns Hostile," ''New York Times'', August 7, 2009.]</ref> as well as various other anti-government run health care protests.<ref>[http://www.wtok.com/news/headlines/53172462.html Grassroots Group Grabs Attention<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718123330/http://www.wtok.com/news/headlines/53172462.html |date=2011-07-18 }}</ref>
In February 2010, Tea Party Patriots was among the twelve most influential groups in the Tea Party movement, according to the ''[[National Journal]]''.<ref name=nj20100204>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/njonline/12-tea-party-players-to-watch-20100204 |title=12 Tea Party Players To Watch |magazine=[[National Journal]] |date=February 4, 2010 |accessdate=April 17, 2015 |first1=Christopher |last1=Snow Hopkins |first2=Siddhartha |last2=Mahanta |first3=Theresa |last3=Poulson}}</ref> In September 2010, the group announced it had received a $1,000,000 donation from an anonymous donor.<ref name= "million">[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-09-21/tea-party-patriots-to-hand-out-1-million-for-november-election-spending.html Tea Party Patriots to Hand Out $1 Million for November Election Spending]</ref> The money was distributed to its affiliated groups and must be spent by [[United States elections, 2010|Election Day]], though it could not be used to directly support any candidate.<ref name= "million" /> Tea Party Patriots was one of the top five most influential organizations in the Tea Party movement, according to the ''[[Washington Post]]''.<ref name="wapo20100926">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/graphic/2010/09/26/GR2010092600175.html |title=The top national players in the tea party |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=September 26, 2010 |accessdate=April 17, 2015}}</ref>
In 2012, the group along with the Southern Republican Leadership Conference organized a presidential debate that aired on CNN.<ref>[http://www.teapartypatriots.org/presidential-debate/ TPP Sponsors Presidential Debate in Charleston, SC | Tea Party PatriotsTea Party Patriots<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Along with various other [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]] and [[Libertarianism in the United States|libertarian]] organizations the Tea Party Patriots have developed a [[Contract from America]] that echoes the Republican [[Contract with America]] of 1994 stating some of the core principles and several specific goals shared by organizations and individuals involved with the tea parties.<ref>[http://www.thecontract.org/about/ Contract from America: About Us]</ref>{{Failed verification|date=June 2011}}
In July 2012 the group's [[Atlanta]] chapter partnered with the [[Sierra Club]] and the [[NAACP]] to defeat a proposed transit tax in Atlanta. The [[referendum]] was defeated by a margin of 63 percent.<ref>http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Politics/2012/0801/How-tea-party-and-its-unlikely-allies-nixed-Atlanta-s-transit-tax</ref>
==Controversies==
''[[Rolling Stone]]'' and [[Talking Points Memo]] have alleged that the organization is run with the help of [[FreedomWorks]], a [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]] nonprofit.<ref>[http://tpmmuckraker.talkingpointsmemo.com/2009/08/freedomworks_says_jump_tea_partiers_ask_how_high.php FreedomWorks Says Jump, Tea Partiers Ask How High | TPMMuckraker<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/story/30219673/the_lie_machine The Lie Machine : Rolling Stone<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Tea Party Patriots denies this claim.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}}
A 2011 investigation by the magazine ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'' alleged that the Tea Party Patriots organization was using its 501(c)(4) status to avoid disclosing its expenditures both to the IRS and to local contributors. The magazine reported that when local Tea Party groups pressed for more details on the group's expenses, they were removed from the umbrella organization and threatened with legal action.<ref>[http://motherjones.com/politics/2011/02/tea-party-patriots-investigated-part-two "Tea Party Patriots Investigated: Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell," ''Mother Jones'', February 15, 2011.]</ref> The magazine reported that Tea Party Patriots "has started to resemble the Beltway lobbying operations its members have denounced."<ref>[https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2011/02/tea-party-patriots-investigated "Tea Party Patriots Investigated: They Use You and Abuse You," ''Mother Jones'', February 14, 2011], retrieved November 10, 2016.</ref>
In 2014, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported that Tea Party Patriots president Jenny Beth Martin was receiving two salaries from the organization: a $15,000 per month fee for strategic consulting and a $272,000 salary as president, with total annual compensation over $450,000.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/tea-party-pacs-reap-money-for-midterms-but-spend-little-on-candidates/2014/04/26/0e52919a-cbd6-11e3-a75e-463587891b57_story.html "Tea Party PACs reap money for midterms but spend little on candidates," ''The Washington Post'', April 26, 2014], retrieved November 10, 2016.</ref>

'''The Alvin Weinberg Foundation''' was a registered UK [[Charitable organization|charity]], operating under the name '''Weinberg Next Nuclear''', that campaigns for [[research and development]] into [[Generation_IV_reactor|next-generation nuclear energy]]. In particular, it advocates advancement of [[Liquid fluoride thorium reactor|Liquid Fluoride Thorium Reactor]] (LFTR) and other [[Molten Salt Reactor]] (MSR) technologies.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Scott|first1=Katie|title=Thorium: the element that could power our future|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2011-09/16/a-nuclear-future|accessdate=28 December 2015|work=[[Wired UK]]|publisher=[[Condé Nast]]|date=16 September 2011}}</ref>
It was named for Dr [[Alvin M. Weinberg]], Director of [[Oak Ridge National Laboratory]] between 1955–1973 and the main advocate of MSR development.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Clark|first1=Duncan|title=Thorium advocates launch pressure group|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/blog/2011/sep/09/thorium-weinberg-foundation|accessdate=28 December 2015|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|date=9 September 2011}}</ref>
==History== * September 2011: Launched at [[House of Lords]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Launching The Weinberg Foundation|url=http://www.itheo.org/articles/launching-weinberg-foundation|website=International Thorium Energy Organisation, IThEO|accessdate=28 December 2015}}</ref> * January 2014: Becomes a [[Charitable_organization#Charity_registration|Registered Charity]] in [[England and Wales]]. * May 2015: [[Stephen Tindale]] joins as Director.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Tindale|first1=Stephen|title=Why I have joined the Alvin Weinberg Foundation|url=http://www.the-weinberg-foundation.org/2015/06/04/why-i-have-joined-the-alvin-weinberg-foundation/|website=The Alvin Weinberg Foundation|accessdate=28 December 2015}}</ref> * July 2017: The Weinberg Foundation dissolved.
==People== * [[Bryony Worthington, Baroness Worthington|Baroness Worthington]] is trustee and patron.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cookson|first1=Clive|title=New life for forgotten fuel|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/52d7bde6-e401-11e0-bc4e-00144feabdc0.html|work=[[Financial Times]]|publisher=[[The Nikkei]]|date=23 September 2011|accessdate=28 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Alvin Weinberg Foundation - Trustees|url=http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/ContactAndTrustees.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=1155255&SubsidiaryNumber=0|website=Registered Charities|publisher=[[Charity Commission for England and Wales]]|accessdate=28 December 2015}}</ref> * [[Stephen Tindale]], who led [[Greenpeace]] in the UK from 2000 until 2005, was its last Director.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Connor|first1=Steve|title=Nuclear power? Yes please...|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/green-living/nuclear-power-yes-please-1629327.html|accessdate=28 December 2015|work=[[The Independent]]|date=23 February 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Lynas|first1=Mark|title=The God Species|date=2012|publisher=Fourth Estate|location=London|isbn=978-0-00-737522-6|page=181}}</ref>

[http://www.podbean.com/podcast-detail?pid=15826/ Podbean] }} '''''The Political Cesspool''''' is a weekly [[far-right]] [[talk radio]] show founded by [[Tennessee|Tennessean]] political activist James Edwards and syndicated by the organizations Liberty News Radio Network and [[Accent Radio Network]] in the United States. First broadcast in October 2004 twice a week from radio station [[WMQM]], per Edwards it has been [[simulcast]] on Stormfront Radio, a service of the [[white nationalist]] [[Stormfront (website)|Stormfront]] website<ref>The Political Cesspool: [http://www.thepoliticalcesspool.org/blog/2008/04/04/an-encouraging-and-comprehensive-update/ An Encouraging and Comprehensive Update] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080708141007/http://www.thepoliticalcesspool.org/blog/2008/04/04/an-encouraging-and-comprehensive-update/ |date=July 8, 2008 }} (dead link)</ref> and as of 2011 is broadcast on Saturday nights on [[WLRM]], a [[Christian radio|Christian]] radio station in [[Millington, Tennessee]]. Its sponsors include the [[white separatism|white separatist]] [[Council of Conservative Citizens]] and the [[Institute for Historical Review]], a [[Holocaust denial]] group.<ref name=Holthouse/>
According to its statement of principles, the show stands for the "Dispossessed Majority" and represents "a philosophy that is pro-White."<ref name="statement"/> It has attracted criticism—including from ''[[The Nation (magazine)|The Nation]]'', ''[[The New Republic]]'', the [[Stephen Roth Institute]], the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] (SPLC), and the [[Anti-Defamation League]]—for its promotion of [[antisemitism|anti-semitic]], [[white nationalism|white nationalist]] and [[white supremacy|white supremacist]] views.<ref>{{cite news|last=Conant|first=Eve|title=Rebranding Hate in the Age of Obama|url=http://www.newsweek.com/2009/04/24/rebranding-hate-in-the-age-of-obama.html|accessdate=September 2, 2010|newspaper=Newsweek|date=April 25, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Pat Buchanan Appears on Political Cesspool, a White Supremacist Radio Show|url=http://www.adl.org/main_Extremism/Buchanan_Edwards.htm|publisher=Anti-Defamation League|accessdate=September 2, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100806211041/http://www.adl.org/main_Extremism/Buchanan_Edwards.htm|archivedate=August 6, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref> According to the SPLC, the show has featured a "Who's Who of the radical right", including members of the [[Ku Klux Klan]]; they say Edwards has probably done more than anyone in America to promote neo-Nazis, Holocaust deniers and other extremists.<ref>Zaitchik, Alexander. [http://www.splcenter.org/get-informed/intelligence-report/browse-all-issues/2006/winter/hawking-racism "Hawking Racism"], Southern Policy Law Center, Intelligence Report, Winter 2006, Issue 124. * [http://www.splcenter.org/get-informed/intelligence-report/browse-all-issues/2007/fall/memphis-sewage/james-edwards-in-his-own "James Edwards: In His Own Words"], Southern Poverty Law Center, Intelligence Report, Fall 2007, Issue 27. Retrieved September 29, 2010.</ref>
The show features Edwards and his co-hosts Keith Alexander, Bill Rolen, Winston Smith, and Eddie Miller, as well as producer Art Frith. Former staffers include Geoff Melton, Jess Bonds and co-founder Austin Farley. Its guests have included author [[Jerome Corsi]], [[Minuteman Project]] leader [[Jim Gilchrist]], former [[Constitution Party (United States)|Constitution Party]] presidential candidate [[Michael Peroutka]], actor [[Sonny Landham]], [[British National Party]] leader [[Nick Griffin]], [[Vermont]] secessionist [[Thomas Naylor]], and [[paleoconservative]] activist [[Pat Buchanan]]. It is carried by at least three licensed terrestrial radio stations in the United States and on network feeds on the [[Galaxy 19]] communications satellite.
==Background==
===James Edwards=== Edwards is a [[Far-right politics|far-right]] political activist from [[Memphis, Tennessee]], described by the Southern Poverty Law Center as a rising star of the modern white-nationalist movement. They write that he is articulate, charming, and at ease in front of the public, as well as in television and radio studios. He attended [[Briarcrest Christian School]], a private school in Memphis, and in ninth grade transferred into a Christian-nationalist homeschooling program, a decision that he said led him into political activism.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/intelligence-report/2007/racist-memphis-radio-host-celebrated-council-conservative-citizens-conference|title=Racist Memphis Radio Host Celebrated at Council of Conservative Citizens Conference|publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]|access-date=2018-05-02|date = October 1, 2007|first = David|last=Holthouse|language=en}}</ref> In 2000 he volunteered for Pat Buchanan's [[Pat Buchanan#2000 presidential campaign|presidential campaign]], and in 2002 ran unsuccessfully for the [[Tennessee House of Representatives]]. It was during this campaign that he met fellow activist Austin Farley, who was on the ballot against him.<ref name=Holthouse>{{cite news|url=http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?aid=817|title=Memphis Sewage|accessdate=April 28, 2009|publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]: [[Southern Poverty Law Center#Intelligence Report|Intelligence Report]]|date=Fall 2007|first=David|last=Holthouse|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090817201047/http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?aid=817|archivedate=August 17, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In October of that year, he and Farley established ''The Political Cesspool''.<ref name="flyer">{{cite web|url=http://www.memphisflyer.com/JacksonBaker/archives/2005/09/23/crossroads-politics|title=Crossroads Politics|first=Jackson|last=Baker|work=[[Memphis Flyer]]|accessdate=February 21, 2010}}</ref>
In 2007, Edwards was part of a panel that appeared on [[CNN]]'s ''[[Paula Zahn Now]]'', along with [[Roland S. Martin]] and [[Jesse Lee Peterson]]. The purpose was to discuss [[racial segregation]] in American cities. He told Zahn that white children should seek out those who share "the same values and traditions and heroes," and that "forced integration" was a "march toward [[totalitarianism]]." He said: "Crime and violence follow African-Americans wherever they go, and if you think that is racist, then spend some time on the mean streets of south Memphis."<ref name=Holthouse/> Martin described his remarks as unfit for national television.<ref name="spl798">{{cite web|url=http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?aid=798|title=Into the Mainstream|publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]: [[Southern Poverty Law Center#Intelligence Report|Intelligence Report]]|accessdate=November 14, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091018171153/http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?aid=798|archivedate=October 18, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Edwards made a second appearance on ''Paula Zahn Now'' in 2009, during which he said: "Whites are in for the fight of their lives. America is becoming [[Balkanization|balkanized]]. We are being robbed of having a future in the very nation our ancestors carved from the wilderness."<ref name=Holthouse/>
In 2010, he became involved with a new party, the [[American Freedom Party]], which advocates white nationalism and a form of [[economic nationalism]] known as the [[Third Position]].<ref name="a3p">{{cite web|url=http://american3p.org/?p=377|title=Bill Johnson to Guest on ‘The Political Cesspool’ this Saturday|publisher=[[American Third Position Party]]|accessdate=February 22, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100220170905/http://american3p.org/?p=377|archivedate=February 20, 2010|df=mdy-all}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.adl.org/main_Extremism/Backgrounder:+American+Third+Position.htm?Multi_page_sections=sHeading_1|title=Formation of the American Third Position Party|accessdate=May 22, 2010|publisher=Anti-Defamation League|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100414134013/http://www.adl.org/main_Extremism/Backgrounder%3A+American+Third+Position.htm?Multi_page_sections=sHeading_1|archivedate=April 14, 2010|df=mdy-all}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.adl.org/main_Extremism/Backgrounder%3a+American+Third+Position.htm?Multi_page_sections=sHeading_5|title=Leaders of the A3P: James Edwards, Director|accessdate=May 22, 2010|publisher=Anti-Defamation League|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100412050013/http://www.adl.org/main_Extremism/Backgrounder%3A+American+Third+Position.htm?Multi_page_sections=sHeading_5|archivedate=April 12, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Also in 2010 he self-published a book, ''Racism, Schmacism: How Liberals use the "R" Word to Push the Obama Agenda'', distributed by [[CreateSpace]], a [[self-publishing]] printer.<ref name="book">{{cite web|url=http://www.thepoliticalcesspool.org/|title=Racism, Schmacism|accessdate=June 5, 2010}}</ref>
===Staff and show history=== Other staff at ''The Political Cesspool'' include Bill Rolen, Eddie "The Bombardier" Miller, Keith Alexander,<ref name="keithalexander">{{cite web|url=http://www.thepoliticalcesspool.org/jamesedwards/tag/edmund-connelly-interview/|title=Edmund Connelly loves The Political Cesspool|first=James|last=Edwards|publisher=The Political Cesspool|accessdate=April 6, 2010}}</ref> and Winston Smith. According to the show's website, most of the staff claim descent from [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] soldiers.<ref name="about"/><ref name="crew">{{cite web|url=http://www.thepoliticalcesspool.org/thecrew.php|title=The Crew|publisher=The Political Cesspool|accessdate=November 14, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100702214944/http://www.thepoliticalcesspool.org/thecrew.php|archivedate=July 2, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The show was initially broadcast on AM 1600 [[WMQM]], a Memphis-based radio station, on Tuesdays and Thursdays. Edwards and Farley invited friends Bill Rolen, a board member of the [[Council of Conservative Citizens]],<ref name="crew" /> and Jess Bonds as guest hosts, as well as radio technician Art Frith. Frith had previously worked for a number of other radio stations including [[American Forces Network|American Forces Radio and Television Service]] (AFRTS) (in [[Keflavik, Iceland]]; [[Anchorage, Alaska]]; and [[Nea Makri, Greece]]), [[KFQD]] (in Anchorage), and [[WTOU|WBCK]] (in [[Battle Creek, Michigan]]).<ref name="crew" />
In 2005 the group moved to WMQM's Millington-based sister station, AM 1380 [[WLRM]], and switched to a nightly schedule, Monday through Friday. Farley left the program in November of that year.<ref name=Holthouse /><ref name="wmc6">{{cite web |url= http://www.wmcstations.com/Global/story.asp?S=4577536 |title=Mid-South radio show added to hate group watch list|publisher=[[WMC-TV]]|accessdate=October 3, 2009 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071205153726/http://www.wmcstations.com/Global/story.asp?S=4577536 |archivedate = December 5, 2007}}</ref> Two years later, Geoff Melton, a former co-host, joined to help set up the show's website and the show entered syndication with Dixie Broadcasting Radio Network. The program went on hiatus on February 15, 2008, because staff members said they needed a break,<ref name="about" /> but returned to the airwaves in June 2008 on WLRM on Saturday nights. One year later, it switched from [[Republic Broadcasting Network]] to Liberty News Radio Network.<ref name="rbn">{{cite web|url=http://www.thepoliticalcesspool.org/jamesedwards/2009/03/14/|title=Political Cesspool to join Liberty News Radio Network|first=James|last=Edwards|publisher=The Political Cesspool|accessdate=April 6, 2010}}</ref> As of August 2009, Bonds and Melton are no longer affiliated with the program.<ref name="about" /> Frith now lives in [[Nashville, Michigan]], but remains a part of the show's staff.<ref name="crew" /> Since WLRM is not audited by [[Arbitron]], the show's ratings are unknown.<ref name=Holthouse/><ref name="noise">{{Cite news | last = Davis | first = Chris | title = ''White Noise'' | newspaper = [[Memphis Flyer]] | location = [[Memphis, Tennessee]] | pages = 12 | publisher = Kenneth Neill | date = November 13, 2008 | url = http://www.memphisflyer.com/memphis/white-noise/Content?oid=1308051 | accessdate = March 17, 2010}}</ref> The show is listener-supported and, according to Edwards, receives more donations from Florida than from any other state.<ref name="florida">{{cite web|url=http://www.thepoliticalcesspool.org/jamesedwards/tpc-making-headlines-this-week-from-phoenix-to-miami/|title=TPC making headlines this week from Phoenix to Miami|accessdate=July 24, 2010|first=James|last=Edwards|work=The Political Cesspool}}</ref>
==Statement of principles== ''The Political Cesspool'' describes its philosophy as "pro-White" and "against political centralization". Its statement of principles, with material borrowed from the [[Council of Conservative Citizens]],<ref name="appeal" /> reads:
{{quote|''The Political Cesspool Radio Program'' stands for The Dispossessed Majority. We represent a philosophy that is pro-White and are against political centralization. You can trust ''The Political Cesspool'' to give you the "other side of the news"—to report on events which are vital to your welfare but which would otherwise be hushed up or distorted by the controlled press.
We make no attempt to give you "both sides." We'll leave the establishment side to your daily newspaper, television and other radio shows. We will bring to you some of the most renowned thinkers, writers, pundits, activists, entertainers and elected officials each broadcast as our guests. Furthermore, we pledge that The Political Cesspool will correct any meaningful error or fact. Make up your own mind who is being honest with you: the establishment media or ''The Political Cesspool Radio Program''.
# The United States government should be independent of any international organization of governments and American law should not be imposed by organizations such as the United Nations. # America would not be as prosperous, ruggedly individualistic, and a land of opportunity if the founding stock were not Europeans. # Since family is the foundation of any strong society, we are against [[feminism]], abortion, and [[Anarcho-primitivism|primitivism]]. # Private property rights are inviolable. They come from our God-given right to life. # We wish to revive the White birthrate above replacement level fertility and beyond to grow the percentage of Whites in the world relative to other races. # Issues such as education, environmental law, and police should be decentralized down to the lowest level to insure natural rights and efficiency. # [[Secession]] is a right of all people and individuals. It was successful in 1776 and this show honors those who tried to make it successful in 1865. # We are [[Social conservatism|cultural conservatives]] because we have certain morals to which we adhere. We are against [[homosexuality]], vulgarity, loveless sex, and [[Sadomasochism|masochism]]. # We wish for American government to stop interfering politically, militarily, and socially outside of the borders of the United States of America. We want non-interventionism.<ref name="statement">{{cite web|url=http://www.thepoliticalcesspool.org/mission/|title=Statement of Principles|publisher=The Political Cesspool|accessdate=October 3, 2009}}</ref>}}

Wyman Institute for Holocaust Studies]]|accessdate=April 16, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728002557/http://www.wymaninstitute.org/articles/HolocaustDenial2007.pdf|archivedate=July 28, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="latimes" /> economists, and musicians.<ref name="pcgl" /> Former Tennessee [[gubernatorial]] candidate Carl "Twofeathers" Whitaker, who claims partial [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native-American]] ancestry and is known for his strong support of the [[Minuteman Project|Minuteman]] movement,<ref name="flyer" /> has appeared on the show, as has conservative Native-American activist David Yeagley.<ref name="pcgl" /> Filmmakers [[Merlin Miller]] (''[[A Place to Grow]]'', ''[[Jericho (2001 film)|Jericho]]''), who is the 2012 presidential nominee of the [[American Freedom Party]], and Craig Bodeker (''A Conversation about Race'')<ref name="adlar">{{cite web|url=http://www.adl.org/main_Extremism/2010_amren_conference.htm|title=2010 AmRen Conference|publisher=[[Anti-Defamation League]]|accessdate=February 21, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100127201916/http://www.adl.org/main_Extremism/2010_amren_conference.htm|archivedate=January 27, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref> have featured.<ref name="pcgl">{{cite web|url=http://www.thepoliticalcesspool.org/guestlist.php |title=The Political Cesspool: Guest List |publisher=The Political Cesspool |accessdate=May 1, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222232315/http://www.thepoliticalcesspool.org/guestlist.php |archivedate=February 22, 2012 |df= }}</ref>

news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/08/13/AR2008081303959.html|title=''New Books Aim To Unweave the Obama Narrative''|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|location=Washington, D.C.|first=Eli|last=Saslow|date= August 14, 2008|accessdate=June 24, 2010}}</ref> and that the President "rejects everyone white, including his mother and his grandparents".<ref web|url=http://www.adl.org/special_reports/rage-grows-in-America/birther-movement.asp|title=Rage Grows in America: Anti‑Government Conspiracies: The "Birther" Movement|publisher=Anti-Defamation League|accessdate=November 16, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091119065731/http://www.adl.org/special_reports/rage-grows-in-America/birther-movement.asp|archivedate=November 19, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="spl992">{{cite web|url=http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?aid=992|title=Jerome Corsi Appears on White Supremacist Radio|publisher=[[Southern [[John Derbyshire]]<ref name="derb">{{cite web|url=http://www.adl.org/main_Extremism/mencken_club_meeting.htm|title=Racist Gathering Planned for Late October in Maryland|publisher=[[Anti-Defamation [[Constitution Party (United States)|Constitution Party]] nominee [[Michael Peroutka]] used his appearance in 2004 to promote his presidential campaign. Party member Michael Goza described the show as "Christian/Constitutionalist", and "a great blessing to our cause".<ref name="peroutka">{{cite web |url= http://www.peroutka2004.com/schedule/index.php?action=eventview&event_id=718 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20061023065400/http://www.peroutka2004.com/schedule/index.php?action=eventview&event_id=718 |dead-url= yes |archive-date= October 23, 2006 |title=The Political Cesspool w/James Edwards and Austin Farley|publisher=[[Constitution Party (United States)|Constitution Party]]|accessdate=May 1, 2009}}</ref> [[Thomas Naylor]], of the Vermont [[secessionist]] organization [[Second Vermont Republic]], appeared on the show to celebrate [[Confederate History Month]] in April 2007,<ref name="global">{{cite web |url= http://www.globalpolicy.org/nations/emerging/2008/0605vermont.htm |title=North Meets South: Vermont Secessionists Meet with Racist League of the South |publisher=[[Global Policy Forum]]|first=Heidi|last=Beirich|accessdate=May 1, 2009}}</ref> while American Freedom Party Chairman Bill Johnson appeared to promote his party.<ref name="a3p" />
On May 8, 2006, Minuteman Project leader [[Jim Gilchrist]] spoke on the program. Co-host Bill Rolen agreed with Gilchrist's view that illegal immigrants' intentions are to "just squat here and plunder whatever social benefits our programs provide them". However, Rolen disagreed with Gilchrist's claim that illegal immigration was "the 21st century [[slave trade (Americas)|slave trade]]".<ref name="spl642">{{cite web|url=http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?aid=642|title=White Hot|publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]: [[Southern Poverty Law Center#Intelligence Report|Intelligence Report]]|accessdate=August 13, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090909034850/http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?aid=642|archivedate=September 9, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Gilchrist's colleague in the Minuteman movement, [[Chris Simcox]], has also been a guest of the show.<ref name="amchron">{{cite web|url=http://www.americanchronicle.com/articles/view/107153 |title=Minuteman imposter Shawna Ford charged in double murder |work=American Chronicle |accessdate=December 5, 2009 |date=June 23, 2009 |first=Michael |last=Webster |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100421235219/http://www.americanchronicle.com/articles/view/107153 |archivedate=April 21, 2010 |df= }}</ref>
Paul Babeu, the sheriff of [[Pinal County, Arizona]], appeared on ''The Political Cesspool'' on July 10, 2010 to discuss illegal immigration; during the interview, he referred to James Edwards as a "great American".<ref name="mccain"/> Less than two weeks later, Babeu's spokesman issued an apology, saying that he had not researched the show thoroughly enough before scheduling the interview and that Babeu has a policy of not conducting interviews with hate groups. Babeu himself said that he was "hoodwinked" into appearing on the show and that he rejects "any hate or bigotry".<ref name="babeu3"/> Prior to the interview, cohost Eddie Miller said that "Of all the people we’ve interviewed on this radio show, I would say the only people that came close to getting me this excited was Dr. David Duke."<ref name="babeu"/><ref name="babeu2">{{cite web|url=http://www.kgun9.com/Global/story.asp?S=12840579|title=Arizona sheriff apologizes for radio appearance|publisher=KGUN 9|accessdate=July 20, 2010}} {{Dead link|date=April 2012|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Following Babeu's spokesman's apology, Edwards alleged that Babeu was aware of the show's true ideology prior to appearing on the show, saying: "For Sheriff Babeu to change his mind and now regret coming on our show, for whatever reason, is his right. For him to act as though he had no idea of our ideology is a lie."<ref name="babeu3">{{cite web|url=http://www.kgun9.com/Global/story.asp?S=12842962|title=Sheriff Babeu sorry for appearing on radio show tied to hate group|first=Steve|last=Nunez|publisher=KGUN 9|accessdate=July 21, 2010|date=July 20, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100726050228/http://www.kgun9.com/Global/story.asp?S=12842962 <!--Added by H3llBot-->|archivedate=July 26, 2010}}</ref><ref name="babeu">{{cite web|url=http://azstarnet.com/news/local/border/article_32db84f6-9424-11df-a712-001cc4c002e0.html|title=Host says Sheriff Babeu knew of program's 'pro-White' beliefs|first=Tim|last=Steller|work=Arizona Daily Star|date=July 20, 2010|accessdate=July 20, 2010}}</ref><ref name="babeu4">{{cite web|url=http://azstarnet.com/news/local/border/article_b4ddb3e5-6e02-515a-8b2f-557c9ff1d4ff.html|title=Lawman backs off interview on 'white' show|work=Arizona Daily Star|date=July 21, 2010|accessdate=July 21, 2010|first=Tim|last=Steller}}</ref> As a result of the controversy surrounding Babeu's appearance on the show, Arizona [[U.S. Senate]] candidate [[J. D. Hayworth]] asked his primary opponent, [[John McCain]], to drop several campaign ads featuring McCain and Babeu.<ref name="mccain">{{cite web|url=http://www.azcentral.com/news/articles/2010/07/21/20100721hayworth-mccain-pinal-sheriff-interview0722.html|title=Hayworth asks McCain to dump Pinal County Sheriff ads|accessdate=July 22, 2010|date=July 21, 2010|first=Lindsey|last=Collum|work=Arizona Republic}}</ref> In 2011, another sheriff, Dennis Spruell of [[Montezuma County, Colorado]], also apologized after appearing on the show without knowing its actual agenda.<ref name="spruell">{{cite web|url=http://fourcornersfreepress.com/news/2011/031107.htm|title=Sheriff distances himself from radio show|publisher=Four Corners Free Press|date=March 9, 2011|accessdate=April 19, 2011}}</ref>
{{double image|left|2008 Jared Taylor.jpg|150|Nick griffin bnp from flickr user britishnationalism (cropped).jpg|150|American "racial realist" Jared Taylor and British far-right politician Nick Griffin have both been repeat guests on the show; both have argued for forms of racial segregation in order to protect the Caucasian race from what they see as the negative influences of other racial groups.}}
Paleoconservative activist and former presidential candidate Pat Buchanan has appeared twice as of 2011.<ref name="avlon"/> In a June 2008 interview initiated and arranged by his publicist, he promoted his book ''[[Churchill, Hitler and the Unnecessary War]]''. During the broadcast, Buchanan defended [[Charles Lindbergh]] against charges of antisemitism, stating that his reputation "has been blackened because of a single speech he gave and a couple of paragraphs in it where he said that ... the Jewish community is beating the drums for war but frankly, no one has said what he said was palpably untrue." At the end of the interview, James Edwards said, "Mr. Buchanan, thank you so much for coming back on our program, for fighting for our people." Previously, in September 2006, Buchanan had made an appearance to promote his book ''[[State of Emergency (book)|State of Emergency]]''; during this interview, he said that "we are being invaded by people of different cultures" and argued that Americans "cannot survive a bifurcated culture or a heavily Hispanicized culture, tilted towards [[Mexico]] ... I think that's the beginning of the end of the United States." <ref name=adlbuch2>{{cite web|url=http://www.adl.org/special_reports/Patrick_Buchanan2/extremists.asp|title=Patrick Buchanan|publisher=[[Anti-Defamation League]]|accessdate=August 17, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100414080654/http://www.adl.org/special_reports/Patrick_Buchanan2/extremists.asp|archivedate=April 14, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="tnr">{{cite web|url=http://www.tnr.com/blog/the-plank/pat-buchanan-advertises-his-book-neo-nazi-radio-show|title=Pat Buchanan Advertises His Book On Radio Show|first=James|last=Kirchick|work=[[The New Republic]]|accessdate=February 25, 2010}}</ref>
Self-proclaimed "[[Scientific racism|racial realist]]" [[Jared Taylor]], whom James Edwards considers to be a close friend,<ref name="about" /> has appeared on at least ten occasions.<ref name="taylor">{{cite web|url=http://www.adl.org/NR/exeres/55F644A0-06E3-4436-BBA5-DD19C5C36576,DB7611A2-02CD-43AF-8147-649E26813571,frameless.htm|title=Jared Taylor/American Renaissance|publisher=[[Anti-Defamation League]]|accessdate=February 25, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100410062551/http://www.adl.org/NR/exeres/55F644A0-06E3-4436-BBA5-DD19C5C36576,DB7611A2-02CD-43AF-8147-649E26813571,frameless.htm|archivedate=April 10, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In an article he wrote for ''[[VDARE]]'', Taylor described the program as "racially oriented".<ref name="jared">{{cite web|url=http://vdare.com/taylor/100316_ar2010.htm|title=Reap the Whirlwind|first=Jared|last=Taylor|publisher=[[VDARE]]|accessdate=March 17, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100325012747/http://www.vdare.com/taylor/100316_ar2010.htm|archivedate=March 25, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Although describing itself as "America First",<ref name="donations">{{cite web|url=http://www.thepoliticalcesspool.org/donations.php|title=The Political Cesspool Donations Page|publisher=The Political Cesspool|accessdate=August 9, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081026060058/http://www.thepoliticalcesspool.org/donations.php|archivedate=October 26, 2008|df=mdy-all}}</ref> the show has also hosted foreign guests, including [[Croatian people|Croatian]] white nationalist [[Tomislav Sunić]], Australian white nationalist [[Drew Fraser]], Russian [[Austrian School]] economist Yuri N. Maltsev, British lawyer [[Adrian Davies (barrister)|Adrian Davies]], Canadian white supremacist [[Paul Fromm (activist)|Paul Fromm]], Canadian conservative blogger [[Kathy Shaidle]], and [[British National Party]] (BNP) leaders [[Simon Darby]] and [[Nick Griffin]]; Griffin appeared as a guest before and after his election to the [[European Parliament]]. During his post-election appearance, Griffin attributed the BNP's electoral successes to a fear of "creeping process of [[Islamification]]".<ref name="pcgl"/><ref name="griffin">{{cite web|url=http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?aid=1107|title=Racist British Party Wins Euro-Seats|publisher=Southern Poverty Law Center|accessdate=December 3, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091208094235/http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?aid=1107|archivedate=December 8, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Actor [[Mel Gibson]]'s father, [[Hutton Gibson]], has also appeared on the show. During his appearance, he referred to [[Pope Benedict XVI]] as a "homosexual" and claimed that "half the people in the [[Holy See|Vatican]] are [[queer]]."<ref name="hutton">{{cite news |title=Gibson’s dad calls Pope gay? |work=Toronto Sun |date=August 10, 2010 |url=http://www.torontosun.com/entertainment/celebrities/2010/08/09/14970896-wenn-story.html |accessdate=October 20, 2010}}</ref>
==Controversy and criticism== The show has frequently been criticised by anti-racist groups and individuals (such as the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] (SPLC), [[Anti-Defamation League]] (ADL),<ref name="adledwards">{{cite web|url=http://www.adl.org/main_Extremism/James+Edwards.htm|title=Following a Four-Month Absence, White Supremacist James Edwards and the Political Cesspool Return to the Airwaves|publisher=Anti-Defamation League|accessdate=November 23, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091003195735/http://www.adl.org/main_Extremism/James+Edwards.htm|archivedate=October 3, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref> [[Stephen Roth Institute]], and journalist [[Max Blumenthal]]) over its stated ideology. ''The Political Cesspool'' was added to the Southern Poverty Law Center's [[hate group]] watch list in 2006. James Edwards was "ecstatic", saying "I don't think you've arrived in the conservative movement until you've made it to the Southern Poverty Law Center's Hate Watch". Edwards describes the SPLC as a group composed of "communists and civil rights hustlers".<ref name="wmc6"/><ref name="appeal" /> The SPLC's Hatewatch has referred to ''The Political Cesspool'' as "an overtly racist, anti-Semitic radio show hosted by [a] self-avowed white nationalist"<ref name="weber">{{cite web|url=http://www.splcenter.org/get-informed/intelligence-files/groups/institute-for-historical-review|title=Institute for Historical Review|publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]|accessdate=March 23, 2010}}</ref> and as "the nexus of hate in America".<ref name="latimes">{{Cite news | last = Rutten | first = Tim | title = ''The Extreme-Right Way to Make a Buck'' | newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]] | location = Los Angeles | pages = A. 21 | publisher = Eddy Harteinstein | date = August 16, 2008 | url = http://articles.latimes.com/2008/aug/16/opinion/oe-rutten16 | accessdate = March 17, 2010}} </ref> The Anti-Defamation League has also criticized the show; Edwards has attacked the ADL as "America's most powerful hate group" and has claimed that its definition of a "neo-Nazi [is] any white person who disagrees with a Jew".<ref name="latimes" /><ref name="disagrees">{{cite web|url=http://www.thepoliticalcesspool.org/jamesedwards/we-made-the-all-star-team/|title=We Made The All Star Team!|accessdate=April 23, 2010|first=James|last=Edwards|publisher=The Political Cesspool}}</ref>
Author [[John Avlon]], a former speechwriter for [[Rudy Giuliani]], has described ''The Political Cesspool'' as "avowedly white supremacist".<ref name="avlon">{{cite book |last = Avlon |first = John |authorlink = John Avlon |title = Wingnuts: How the Lunatic Fringe is Hijacking America |publisher = Beast Books |page = 79 |year = 2010 |isbn = 0-9842951-1-9}}</ref> Investigative journalist Max Blumenthal, who reported on an attempt by one of the show's staff to advertise at a rally for [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] vice-presidential candidate [[Sarah Palin]], described ''The Political Cesspool'' as having a "racist ideology", and highlighted anti-Semitic, racist, and [[homophobia|homophobic]] comments that Edwards had made on his blog.<ref name="max2">{{cite web|url=http://www.thenation.com/doc/20080901/blumenthal|title=Obama Nation Author Jerome Corsi's Racist History Exposed|work=[[The Nation]]|first=Max|last=Blumenthal|accessdate=September 7, 2009}}</ref><ref name="max">{{cite web |url=http://maxblumenthal.com/2008/10/obama-the-neo-nazis-and-the-republican-base/|title=Obama, the Neo-Nazis, and the Republican Base|publisher=[[Max Blumenthal]]|accessdate=April 28, 2009}}</ref> The Stephen Roth Institute has also commented on the show, noting that "[James] Edwards openly espoused many of his guests' views and during speeches to extremist audiences, including members of the white supremacist Council of Conservative Citizens and the racist [[League of the South]], he gained the support of a wide array of extremists." In an article about antisemitism in [[Belgium]], the Institute commented on the show's interview with [[Filip Dewinter]], a member of the Belgian Parliament and a leader of the extremist [[Vlaams Belang]] movement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tau.ac.il/Anti-Semitism/asw2007/usa.html|title=Anti-Semitism in the United States|publisher=[[Stephen Roth Institute]]|accessdate=April 28, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090211062116/http://www.tau.ac.il/Anti-Semitism/asw2007/usa.html|archivedate=February 11, 2009|df=mdy-all}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.tau.ac.il/Anti-Semitism/asw2007/belgium.html|title=Anti-Semitism in Belgium|publisher=[[Stephen Roth Institute]]|accessdate=April 28, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090224211432/http://www.tau.ac.il/Anti-Semitism/asw2007/belgium.html|archivedate=February 24, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
''[[Newsweek]]'' used one of Winston Smith's statements to argue that the rise in popularity of white nationalism and supremacy is due to the combination of the late-2000s recession and the [[United States presidential election, 2008|election of a black president]]. Many such groups have been attempting to gain new recruits and increase their political influence by rebranding themselves as defenders of "white heritage" while de-emphasizing their dislike of minorities and Jews. Smith states, "[t]he emphasis is different now. We don't talk as much about what blacks have done to us; we're more focused on ourselves and our own culture."<ref name=eve>{{cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/2009/04/24/rebranding-hate-in-the-age-of-obama.html|title=Rebranding Hate in the Age Of Obama|accessdate=May 1, 2009|work=Newsweek|date=April 25, 2009|first=Eve|last=Conant}}</ref>
===City Park demonstration=== [[File:Confederate Park Memphis 1.jpg|right|thumb|upright=0.9|alt=Photograph of a crumbling brick wall running up and then alongside a grassy hill which has trees and a lamppost at the top. Brick buildings are visible in the background to the left.|Confederate Park in downtown Memphis, the site of a demonstration organized in 2005 by James Edwards and the staff of ''The Political Cesspool''.]]
In 2005, the staff of ''The Political Cesspool'' organized a rally at the Tennessee area known as Confederate Park, which, along with two other Confederacy-themed parks in downtown Memphis, has been the subject of a longtime controversy for honoring [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] soldiers and ideals.<ref name="flyer" /> The park had been criticized earlier by a black [[Shelby County, Tennessee|Shelby County]] official, which attracted the notice of New York-based activist [[Al Sharpton]], who was invited by the Reverend LaSimba Gray to hold a demonstration in Memphis. Sharpton planned a march called the Rally for Dignity<ref name="forrest">{{Cite news | last = Denney | first = Pamela | title = Monumental Battle | newspaper = [[Memphis Flyer]] | url = http://www.memphisflyer.com/memphis/monumental-battle/Content?oid=1122385 | location = [[Memphis, Tennessee]] | publisher = Kenneth Neill | date = August 19, 2005 | accessdate = March 29, 2010}}</ref> from downtown Memphis to another park honoring Confederate Lieutenant General [[Nathan Bedford Forrest]] who was involved early in the organization of the [[Ku Klux Klan]].<ref>"[http://galenet.galegroup.com/servlet/BioRC Nathan Bedford Forrest]". ''Dictionary of American Biography Base Set''. American Council of Learned Societies, 1928–1936. Reproduced in Biography Resource Center. Farmington Hills, Mich.: Gale, 2010. Subscription required.</ref> Sharpton canceled the march after Edwards and ''The Political Cesspool'' staff obtained a permit to demonstrate in Confederate Park, located along Sharpton's planned march route.<ref name=Holthouse />
Sharpton settled for a protest at Forrest Park. At the demonstration, he argued that "We need to show the rest of the world that the day for honoring people like this is over", and said in an interview that his objections were not related to race but to Forrest's Civil War-era (1861–1865) actions against the United States.<ref name="forrest"/> Estimates of attendance at the rallies vary; according to the Southern Poverty Law Center, James Edwards attracted about 200 white counter-demonstrators to the Confederate Park vigil, while Sharpton's protest at Forrest Park attracted a few dozen black demonstrators, whom Edwards referred to as "rabble".<ref name=Holthouse/> The ''Memphis Flyer'' estimated that Sharpton attracted about 250 supporters.<ref name="forrest" /> In the aftermath of the city park controversy, show affiliates Edwards, Farley, Bonds, and Rolen received the "Dixie Defender Award" from the [[Sons of Confederate Veterans]].<ref name="about" />
Later that year, Memphis city councilman E. C. Jones awarded Edwards and Farley with a certificate "in appreciation of outstanding contributions to the community". Edwards and Farley also received an honorary city council membership from Jones, who had previously appeared on ''The Political Cesspool''. According to ''[[The Commercial Appeal]]'', Jones had not listened to the show before the incident, and was unaware of its ideology. After a reporter informed him of the program's agenda, Jones initially refused to apologize. However, after another reporter confronted him with more details about the show's ideology, he changed his view, saying that he probably would not appear again.<ref name="appeal" /> [[Carol Chumney]], another member of the [[Memphis City Council]], was also invited to appear on ''The Political Cesspool'', but ultimately declined the invitation after listening to an episode of the show; Chumney said, "what I heard was about advocating for prostitution ... So I told them I had other commitments."<ref name="appeal">{{Cite news | last = Thomas | first = Wendi C. | title = Wise up, or slip into the 'Cesspool' | newspaper = [[The Commercial Appeal]] | location = [[Memphis, Tennessee]] | pages = A2 | publisher = Joseph Pepe | date = March 5, 2006}}</ref>
===''Le Journal du Dimanche'' interview=== In an interview with the French newspaper ''[[Le Journal du Dimanche]]'', cohost Eddie "Bombardier" Miller described the United Nations as "[[Satan]] on Earth".<ref name="french">{{cite web|url=http://www.lejdd.fr/International/USA/Actualite/L-immigration-illegale-au-coeur-de-la-campagne-228818/|title=L’immigration illégale au coeur de la campagne|publisher=Le Journal du Dimanche|language=French|date=October 23, 2010|accessdate=December 22, 2010}}</ref><ref name="frenglish">{{cite web|url=https://translate.google.com/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=auto&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.lejdd.fr%2FInternational%2FUSA%2FActualite%2FL-immigration-illegale-au-coeur-de-la-campagne-228818%2F|title=Illegal immigration in the heart of the campaign|language=English|publisher=Le Journal du Dimanche|date=October 23, 2010|accessdate=December 22, 2010}}</ref>
===Donald Trump Jr. interview=== In 2016, Edwards co-hosted a [[Super Tuesday]] broadcast that interviewed [[Donald Trump Jr.]], the son of Republican party presidential candidate [[Donald Trump]]. Edwards praised the elder Trump and encouraged his supporters to vote for him.<ref name="trumpjr">{{cite web|author= Eliza Collins|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/2016-gop-primary-live-updates-and-results/2016/03/donald-trump-son-pro-slavery-host-interview-220120?lo=ap_c1|title=Radio personality who interviewed Donald Trump Jr.: Slavery is 'greatest thing' that happened to African Americans|newspaper=Politico|date=March 2, 2016}}</ref>
==Radio stations that air the show== As of 2011, ''The Political Cesspool'' airs on WLRM in Memphis, Tennessee,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thepoliticalcesspool.org/|title=The Political Cesspool Radio Program official website|accessdate=December 18, 2011}}</ref> [[KHQN]] in [[Spanish Fork, Utah]];<ref name="khqn">{{cite web|url=http://www.khqnradio.com/program_schedule.php|title=KHQN Program Schedule|publisher=[[KHQN]]|accessdate=December 18, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120131084558/http://www.khqnradio.com/program_schedule.php|archivedate=January 31, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and the Florida-based [[Accent Radio Network]].<ref name="arn">{{cite web|url=http://spreadsheets.google.com/pub?key=pdMRJvNXBWEubHzkMYFSAEA|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130124191637/http://spreadsheets.google.com/pub?key=pdMRJvNXBWEubHzkMYFSAEA|dead-url=yes|archive-date=January 24, 2013|title=Accent Radio Network program schedule|publisher=[[Accent Radio Network]]|accessdate=December 18, 2011}}</ref> The Accent Radio Network and KHQN air a shortened two-hour version of the show,<ref name="khqn"/><ref name="arn"/> in contrast to the three-hour Liberty News Radio Network (WLRM) version.<ref name="lnrn">{{cite web|url=http://libertynewsradio.com/schedulesat.php |title=Liberty News Radio Saturday Program Schedule |accessdate=June 16, 2010 |publisher=Liberty News Radio Network |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100911232313/http://libertynewsradio.com/schedulesat.php |archivedate=September 11, 2010 }}</ref><ref name="wlrm">{{cite web|url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:OsA0NhbZE-8J:wlrm1380am.com/schedule.php+wlrm+schedule&cd=3&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us|title=WLRM 1380 Program Schedule (Google cache)|accessdate=June 16, 2010|publisher=WLRM 1380 AM}} {{Dead link|date=April 2012|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
ARN and Liberty News Radio Network broadcasts their feeds on separate channels on the [[Galaxy 19]] communications satellite.<ref name="galaxy">{{cite web|url=http://www.galaxy-marketing.com/galaxy_25_@_97_0w.htm|title=Satellite Galaxy 19 Located at 97 Degrees West|publisher=[[Galaxy (satellite)|Galaxy]]|accessdate=October 1, 2009}}</ref>

[[File:LiberianWomen.jpg|thumb|350px|Women of Liberia Mass Action for Peace]] '''Women of Liberia Mass Action for Peace''' is a [[peace movement]] started in 2003 by women in [[Monrovia]], [[Liberia]], Africa, that worked to end the [[Second Liberian Civil War]].<ref name=GNAD>{{cite web |url= http://nvdatabase.swarthmore.edu/content/liberian-women-act-end-civil-war-2003 |title=Liberian women act to end civil war, 2003 |work=Global Nonviolent Action Database |publisher=[[Swarthmore College]] |location=Pennsylvania |accessdate=27 August 2017 }}</ref> Organized by Crystal Roh Gawding and social workers [[Leymah Gbowee]] and [[Comfort Freeman]], the movement began despite Liberia having extremely limited civil rights. Thousands of Muslim and Christian women from various classes mobilized their efforts, staged silent [[nonviolence]] protests that included a [[sex strike]] and the threat of [[Anasyrma|a curse]].
==Background== It was underneath Doe's rule that ones tribal identity determined how they were treated. Doe favored those who shared in his Krhan tribal identity. If someone was indigenous or poor, they were looked down upon by his cabinet and supporters. Signs of war was vastly rising. However, the indigenous were unable to flee the country because of lack of funds. This division led to the start of a long, bloody civil war. During the Liberian Civil War, the reality of women's lives went unreported. Gbowee mentioned some of their roles involved hiding their husbands and sons from soldiers looking to recruit or kill them, walking miles to find food and water for their families, and ultimately how they kept life going so that there would be something left to build on when peace returned. And after gaining power in a military coup in 1989, President Charles Taylor struggled to keep control over the country. Due to the start of tribal identities mattering during Doe's reign, Liberia was now a country divided by rebel factions. Both the rebels and Taylor's administration enforced severe harassment and violence on the people of Liberia. 2003 marked the fourteenth year of the bloody civil war. Many Liberians were displaced, and up to 250,000 lives were taken.<ref>Pray the Devil Back to Hell. Gini Reticker. Fork Films, 2008.</ref> With men being the primary participants of war, the women were the individuals that carried the burden of the wars impact. During the years of warfare, Liberian women "had to endure the pain of watching their young sons be forcibly recruited into the army. A few days later these young men would come back into the same village, drugged up, and were made to execute their own family members. Women had to bear the pain of seeing their young daughters…be used as sex slaves at night and as fighters during the day…women had to sit by and watch their husbands, their fathers be taken away. In most instances these men were hacked to pieces."<ref>Gbowee, Leyman. "Women and Peacebuilding in Liberia: Excerpts from a talk by Leymah Gbowee at the ELCA's Global Mission Event in Milwaukee, WI." Evangelical Lutheran Church in America.</ref> Unable to tolerate any more fighting or killing, a small group of Liberian women made a decision that would eventually change the country. These women released a campaign that called for non-violence and peace. Their leader, Leymah Gbowee, stated that they would "take the destiny of Liberia into their own hands," declaring that "in the past they were silent, but after being killed, raped, dehumanized, and infected with diseases, war has taught them that the future lies in saying no to violence and yes to peace." <ref>Gbowee, Leymah. "Women and Peacebuilding in Liberia: Excerpts from a talk by Leymah Gbowee at the ELCA's Global Mission Event in Milwaukee, WI." Evangelical Lutheran Church in America.</ref>
==Peace deal== In 2003 during the [[Second Liberian Civil War]], Women of Liberia Mass Action for Peace forced a meeting with President [[Charles Taylor (Liberia)|Charles Taylor]] and extracted a promise from him to attend peace talks in [[Ghana]]<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/events/2008/11/inf/GboweeLeymah.html Bio of Gbowee Leymah] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090314222423/http://www.americanprogress.org/events/2008/11/inf/GboweeLeymah.html |date=March 14, 2009 }}</ref> to negotiate with the rebels from [[Liberians United for Reconciliation and Democracy]] and [[Movement for Democracy in Liberia]]. A delegation of Liberian women went to Ghana to continue to apply pressure on the warring factions during the peace process.<ref name="csmonitor.com">[http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Africa/2011/1006/Liberian-women-pray-as-the-nation-heads-to-the-polls Liberian women pray as the nation heads to the polls]</ref>
Two hundred women surrounded the room, dressed in white, dominating the conversation. Any time the negotiators tried to leave, the women threatened to take off all of their clothes. Enclosed in the room with the women, the men would try to jump out of the windows to escape their talk. But the women persisted, staging a [[sit in]] outside of the Presidential Palace. They blocked all the doors and windows and prevented anyone from leaving the peace talks without a resolution.
The women of Liberia became a political force against violence and against their government. Their actions brought about an agreement during the stalled peace talks. As a result, the women were able to achieve peace in [[Liberia]] after a 14-year civil war and later helped bring to power the country's first female head of state, [[Ellen Johnson Sirleaf]].<ref name="csmonitor.com"/> When President Ellen Sirleaf first came into office, she made women's rights one of her priorities. Her administration focused on the condition of women in Liberia and their needs. Some of the changes she made involved: putting more women in office, establishing the Women's Legislative Caucus, a multiparty committee in the House of Representatives that ensures a gender-sensitive approach to the legislature, and creating The Inheritance Act, an act that made rights of inheritance for spouses of statutory and customary marriages. Underneath President Sirleaf, rape, a prominent weapon of war, was also made punishable with a maximum sentence of life in prison.<ref>http://www.africa4womensrights.org/public/Dossier_of_Claims/Liberia-UK.pdf</ref>
==Leaders== Crystal Roh Gawding, President of St.Peter's Lutheran Church Women and Comfort Freeman, National President for All of the Women of Lutheran Church in Liberia, presidents of two different [[Lutheran]] churches, organized the Women in Peacebuilding Network (WIPNET), and issued a statement of intent: "In the past we were silent, but after being killed, raped, dehumanized, and infected with diseases, and watching our children and families destroyed, war has taught us that the future lies in saying NO to violence and YES to peace! We will not relent until peace prevails."<ref>[http://www.myhero.com/go/hero.asp?hero=womens_peace_movement_liberia_08 WOMENS PEACE MOVEMENT OF LIBERIA]</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=How the Women of Liberia Fought for Peace and Won|url=https://tavaana.org/en/content/how-women-liberia-fought-peace-and-won|website=tavaana.org|publisher=E-Collaborative for Civic Education|accessdate=6 September 2016}}</ref> Thousands of local women prayed and sang in a [[fish market]] daily for months.<ref>[http://www.odemagazine.com/blogs/readers_blog/9001/leymah_gbowee_peace_warrior_for_liberia 2009] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091227090728/http://www.odemagazine.com/blogs/readers_blog/9001/leymah_gbowee_peace_warrior_for_liberia |date=December 27, 2009 }}</ref>
'''Asatu Bah Kenneth''', Assistant Minister for Administration and Public Safety of the Liberian Ministry of Justice,<ref>http://unmil.org/1article.asp?id=3718&zdoc=1</ref> was president of the Liberia Female Law Enforcement Association at the time. Inspired by the work of the Christian women's peace initiative, she formed the Liberian Muslim Women's Organization to work for peace.<ref>[http://www.unmultimedia.org/radio/english/detail/64653.html United Nations Radio]</ref>
Together, Gbowee, Freeman and Kenneth brought both groups together to form the Mass Action, a rare thing to happen in Liberia. Since they were brought together, relations have been less tense and more open between Christians and Muslims in [[Liberia]], specifically [[Monrovia]].
The Christian and Muslim women joined forces to create Women of Liberia Mass Action for Peace. They wore white, to symbolize peace.
For her leadership, Leymah Gbowee has received international recognition, including the 2009 John F. Kennedy [[Profile in Courage Award]]<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/moyers/journal/06192009/profile.html Bill Moyers Journal, June 19, 2009]</ref> and the 2011 [[Nobel Peace Prize]].
'''Ellen Johnson Sirleaf,''' The president of Liberia during the duration of the Mass Action for Peace. She often promoted women's rights and promised to increase women's rights in her two campaigns for presidency. She inspired many Liberian women to push for mass movement in order to obtain peace in the country.
==Lasting legacy of WIPSEN== Since the adoption of the [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1325]] in 2000, women have been engaged in rebuilding war-torn societies, restoring relationships and promoting social cohesion. Women Peace and Security Network — Africa (WIPSEN-Africa), is a women-focused, women-led Pan-African Non-Governmental Organization based in [[Ghana]]. It was established on May 8, 2006 to promote women's strategic participation and leadership in peace and security governance in Africa.<ref>[http://www.wipsen-africa.org/wipsen/about/?lang=en-us WIPSEN]</ref>
Leymah Gbowee is the founding member, and served as Executive Director until 2012.<ref>{{cite news | title = WIPSEN EMPOWERS WOMEN...To fight for their rights | url = http://todaygh.com/2011/03/14/wipsen-empowers-women-to-fight-for-their-rights/ | date = December 11, 2010 | work = Ghana Media Group | format = article }}</ref> The organization has a presence in Ghana, [[Nigeria]], [[Ivory Coast]], [[Liberia]] and [[Sierra Leone]].
==Similar protests== * In [[Ivory Coast]], [[Aya Virginie Toure]]<ref>{{cite news | title = Ivory Coast women defiant after being targeted by Gbagbo's guns | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/11/ivory-coast-women-defiant/Women-Play-Vital-Role-In-Egypts-Uprising | date = March 11, 2011 | work = The Guardian | format = article | accessdate = 2011-03-11}}</ref> organized over 40,000 women<ref>{{cite news | title = A plea for help from an Ivorian women's leader amid the violent power struggle | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/p00ff0jq/Outlook_23_03_2011/ | date = March 23, 2011 | work = BBC Radio | format = radio broadcast | accessdate = 2011-03-23}}</ref> in numerous peaceful protests<ref>{{cite news | title = Ivory Coast: women shot dead at anti-Gbagbo rally | url = http://www.euronews.net/2011/03/03/ivory-coast-women-shot-dead-at-anti-gbagbo-rally/ | date = March 3, 2011 | work = Euronews | format = article | accessdate = 2011-03-03}}</ref> in a revolution<ref>{{cite news | title = Ivory Coast's well-armed rebels making quick work of revolution | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/apr/01/ivory-coast-new-forces-rebels-revolution | date = April 1, 2011 | work = The Guardian | format = article | accessdate = 2011-04-01}}</ref> against [[Laurent Gbagbo]]<ref>{{cite news | title = Women in Ivory Coast lead the revolution against Gbagbo | url = http://newscastmedia.com/blog/2011/03/09/women-in-ivory-coast-lead-the-revolution-against-gbagbo/ | date = March 9, 2011 | work = Newscast Media | format = article | accessdate = 2011-03-09}}</ref> in the [[Second Ivorian Civil War]]. Some were dressed in black, some were wearing leaves, and some were naked, all signs of an African [[curse]] directed toward Laurent Gbagbo.<ref>{{cite news | title = The Ivory Coast Effect | url = http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/newsdesk/2011/03/the-ivory-coast-effect.html | date = March 22, 2011 | work = The New Yorker | format = article | accessdate = 2011-03-22}}</ref>
* On March 23, at the [[Economic Community of West African States]] (ECOWAS) Summit in [[Nigeria]],<ref name="Protests">{{cite news | title = ECOWAS Summit: West African women protest Ivorian situation | url = http://www.afriquejet.com/news/africa-news/ecowas-summit:-west-african-women-protest-ivorian-situation-201103246180.html | date = March 24, 2011 | work = Afrique en ligne | format = article | accessdate = 2011-03-24}}</ref> a "One Thousand Women March" was organized by peace activists in West Africa. They wore white T-shirts<ref name="Protests" /> and represented countries across West Africa including Ivory Coast, Ghana, Liberia, Nigeria, Sierra Leone and [[Togo]]. They issued a press release and presented a position statement to the ECOWAS Heads of State.<ref>{{cite news | title = "Thousand Women Protest March" in Solidarity with the Women of Cote d'Ivoire | url = http://www.wipsen-africa.org/wipsen/News/page_3/ | date = March 23, 2011 | work = WIPSEN | format = article | accessdate = 2011-03-23}}</ref>
==Pray the Devil Back to Hell== {{Main|Pray the Devil Back to Hell}} ''Pray the Devil Back to Hell'' is a [[documentary film]] directed by Gini Reticker and produced by [[Abigail Disney]]. The film premiered at the 2008 [[Tribeca Film Festival]], where it won the award for Best Documentary.<ref>[http://www.tribecafilm.com/home/18455719.html Tribeca Film Festival]</ref> The film documents the efforts of Women of Liberia Mass Action for Peace. The film has been used as an [[advocacy]] tool in post-conflict zones like [[Sudan]] and [[Zimbabwe]], mobilizing African women to petition for peace and security.<ref>[http://www.mediaglobal.org/article/2009-11-01/pray-the-devil-back-to-hell-documentary-serves-as-advocacy-tool-in-post-conflict-zones/ November 2009 MEDIAGLOBAL]</ref>
